### Task:

Description: Simulate the spread of an infectious disease using the Partial Differential Equation (PDE) version of the Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered (SIR) model. Explore the impact of transmission and recovery rates on the spatial dynamics of the epidemic.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial S}{\partial t} &= -\beta \cdot \frac{S \cdot I}{N} \\
\frac{\partial I}{\partial t} &= D_i\nabla^2 I + \beta \cdot \frac{S \cdot I}{N} - \gamma \cdot I \\
\frac{\partial R}{\partial t} &= \gamma \cdot I
\end{aligned}
$$

### What model is it:

A **Standard (Non-Spatial) SIR Model** tracks the progression of a disease within a single, homogeneous population solely over **time**,. These models describe individuals moving between susceptible (S), infectious (I), and recovered (R) states using kinetic terms, often expressed using Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) or Discrete Difference Equations.

A **Reaction-Diffusion System** is a mathematical classification for complex phenomena described by Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) that depend on both time and space,. This system combines two components: **Reaction** (local changes, representing kinetic transitions or biological feedback loops) and **Diffusion** (spatial transport or spreading from areas of high concentration to low concentration,).

A **Spatial SIR Model** is explicitly an example of a Reaction-Diffusion system. The key difference is that the Spatial SIR incorporates spatial variables into its equations, simulating disease spread over **time AND space**. The inherent disease dynamics are the "reaction" part, while the spread of infectious individuals across a geographic region (via the ‚àá2 term) is the "diffusion" part, requiring PDEs for its formulation.
